summary: This is an FBI 302 report documenting the return of property to Frank Senerchia, an investigator hired by Jeffrey Epstein's legal counsel, on August 2, 2019. The property, released by the FBI as non-relevant to the investigation, included two suitcases containing valuable items such as loose diamonds, cash, multiple passports, luxury watches, and jewelry.

persons.name: Frank Senerchia
persons.role: Private Investigator for Orion Investigations Inc.
persons.context: Hired by Jeffrey Epstein's legal counsel to take custody of property being released by the FBI. He met with an FBI Special Agent, reviewed the inventory, and signed for the property.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The property being returned belonged to him. The items included his current and expired passports, and the release was coordinated by his legal counsel.

connections.description: Senerchia was tasked by Epstein's legal counsel to retrieve property on Epstein's behalf, indicating a professional service relationship facilitated by Epstein's lawyers.

events.title: FBI Returns Property to Epstein's Representative
events.description: FBI Special Agent met with Frank Senerchia at the FBI's New York office to release property belonging to Jeffrey Epstein that was deemed non-relevant to the investigation. Senerchia reviewed and signed for the items.

locations: 290 Broadway, New York, New York 10007 (FBI office)
New York, New York, United States
keyFacts: On August 2, 2019, the FBI returned a significant cache of Jeffrey Epstein's personal property, deeming it non-relevant to their investigation.

The returned property included items of high value and personal significance: loose diamonds, approximately $50,000 in cash, diamond certificates, multiple luxury watches (including a Richard Mille and an F.P. Journe), and several sets of cufflinks.
The property also included six U.S. passports belonging to Epstein (one current and five expired), and a U.S. Department of Treasury Customs badge.

The retrieval was handled by Frank Senerchia of Orion Investigations Inc., who was specifically tasked by Epstein's legal counsel, indicating an organized effort by Epstein's defense team to secure his assets.
The document is an official FBI record (FD-302) detailing the transfer, with attached receipts and photographic evidence, creating a formal chain of custody for the released items.
